title: 103_s2401
content: The "National Commission on Major League Baseball Act of 1994" establishes the National Commission on Major League Baseball, referred to as the "Commission", with defined membership. The Commission, established by the "National Commission on Major League Baseball Act of 1994", consists of five members appointed by the President for a six-year term. The President appoints members after consultations with various baseball stakeholders and designates one member as Chairman. A majority of members constitute a quorum for meetings. The National Commission on Major League Baseball Act of 1994 establishes a Commission with five members appointed by the President for six-year terms. The first appointments must be made within 60 days of enactment, with the first meeting held within 90 days. All meetings are open to the public, and vacancies are filled within 45 days in the same manner as the original appointment. The Commission oversees and regulates various aspects of Major League Baseball, including arbitration during labor disputes, setting ticket prices, franchise expansion/relocation, stadium financing, TV and marketing revenue regulation, and resolving revenue sharing disputes among owners. The Commission has the authority to hold hearings, obtain data from federal agencies, and issue subpoenas for witnesses and evidence related to Major League Baseball. The Commission has the authority to issue subpoenas for witnesses and evidence related to any matter under investigation. Witnesses may be required to appear at designated places within the judicial district. If a person refuses to obey the subpoena, a court may order them to appear before the Commission. The Commission has the authority to issue subpoenas for witnesses and evidence related to investigations. Failure to obey the court order may result in contempt of court. Subpoenas must be served in accordance with Federal Rules of Civil Procedure. Facilities and support services are provided to the Commission by the Administrator of General Services on a reimbursable basis. The Commission can utilize facilities and services of Federal agencies to aid in its duties. It can also make expenditures and enter contracts for necessary supplies and services within budget limits set by appropriations Acts. Additionally, the Commission is allowed to use the United States mails like other Federal departments. SEC. 6. COMPENSATION OF THE COMMISSION. Each member of the Commission is a full-time Federal employee and paid at an annual rate of basic pay for level II of the Executive Schedule. Members are reimbursed for travel and other necessary expenses. SEC. 7. STAFF OF COMMISSION; EXPERTS AND CONSULTANTS. SEC. 7. STAFF OF COMMISSION; EXPERTS AND CONSULTANTS. The Chairman can appoint up to ten staff members and set their compensation. The Commission can also hire experts and consultants as needed. The Commission will submit a report to Congress on the need for continuing the antitrust exemption for Major League Baseball and the effects of eliminating such exemption. $1,500,000 is authorized for carrying out this Act, which will take effect upon enactment.
